content.content: COVID-19 is a disease caused by SARS-CoV-2, a coronavirus that spreads from one person to another. This illness can range from mild to very serious symptoms and even death.[^250] [About COVID-19 from the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/about-covid-19.html "About COVID-19") Embedded content: https://youtu.be/4drULw46kEE ### Symptoms: - Fatigue - Fever &/or chills - Shortness of breath - Constant cough - Headache - Loss of smell or taste - Body aches - Sore throat - Nausea or vomiting - Diarrhea - Stuffy or runny nose [^251] __Call 911 if you or someone you know has the following__: - Trouble breathing - Constant chest pain or pressure - New confusion - Difficulty waking up or staying awake - Gray or blue lips or face [^251] ### Adults at Higher Risk: - 65 years and older - Cancer - Chronic kidney disease - Obesity - Pregnancy - Smoking - Sickle cell disease - Diabetes - Heart disease - Lung disease [^252] ### Children at Higher Risk: - Obesity - Sickle cell disease - Asthma - Congenital heart disease - Chronic kidney disease - Diabetes - Severe neurologic disease - Inherited metabolic disorders - Severe genetic disorders [^252] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/YEEo3DxUrf0 ### Prevention: Embedded content: https://youtu.be/a7Zz4SxhhvA Embedded content: https://youtu.be/6QdHD4J18vk - Get the COVID-19 vaccination. Everyone who is older than 5 yrs can get this safe and effective vaccine. Use [Vaccines.gov](https://www.vaccines.gov/ "Vaccines.gov"), text your ZIP code to 438829, or call 1-800-232-0233 to find locations in your area. - Wear a close-fitting mask over your nose and mouth indoors in public areas where the [COVID-19 Community Level](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/covid-by-county.html "COVID-19 Community Level") is __high__. - Stay at least 6 feet away from other people who don’t live with you if you aren't up to date on the COVID-19 vaccine. - Avoid poorly ventilated indoor spaces if you are at a high risk of getting very sick from COVID-19. - Wash your hands often with soap & water after being in a public area. - Cover coughs & sneezes. - Clean & disinfect frequently touched surfaces. - Monitor your health daily. - Test for SARS-CoV-2 if you have an infection. A positive result means you should isolate for 5 days and tell your close contacts to stop the spread to others.[^253] - [Test for Current Infection](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/testing/diagnostic-testing.html "Test for Current Infection") ### Testing: Embedded content: https://youtu.be/tIDES6xgalo Embedded content: https://youtu.be/oBrf5BXkOaE Embedded content: https://youtu.be/yoZL1BVP9Bs - If you have COVID-19 symptoms. - If you have been in close contact with someone who has COVID-19. - If you will be traveling on an airplane, are required for your destination, and when you return to the USA. - If your work, school, or an upcoming event requires testing. - If your healthcare provider, [local](https://www.cdc.gov/publichealthgateway/healthdirectories/healthdepartments.html "local") or [state health department](https://www.naccho.org/membership/lhd-directory "state health department") has asked you to get a test. [^254] - [Test for Current Infection](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/testing/diagnostic-testing.html "Test for Current Infection") ### What to Do If You Have COVID-19: Embedded content: https://youtu.be/0m7j3XHVB0Y Embedded content: https://youtu.be/_a7IAkIgZVQ - Stay at home for 5 days. - Stay away from other people & pets in your home. - Wear a mask over your nose and mouth when you are with other people & pets. - Monitor your symptoms. __Call 911 if you or someone you know has: trouble breathing, chest pain, confusion, difficulty waking up, and/or gray or blue lips or face.__ - Do not travel. - Call ahead before visiting your healthcare provider. - Cover your mouth & nose when you cough or sneeze. - Wash your hands often for 20 seconds with soap & water. - Don’t share personal household items. - Clean frequently touched surfaces in your room (& separate bathroom if possible). - Even if you don’t feel sick, you can still spread COVID-19.[^255] [What to Do If You Are Sick](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/steps-when-sick.html "What to Do If You Are Sick") [Quarantine and Isolation ](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/quarantine-isolation.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fcoronavirus%2F2019-ncov%2Fif-you-are-sick%2Fquarantine.html "Quarantine and Isolation ") ### Vaccines: Embedded content: https://youtu.be/ZPENU08rZ-I Embedded content: https://youtu.be/qWG5dou7vW4 Vaccines are one of the best ways to prevent getting COVID-19. Vaccines teach your body how to fight the COVID-19 virus. Everyone who is older than 5 yrs can get the COVID-19 vaccine. __Use [Vaccines.gov](https://www.vaccines.gov/ "Vaccines.gov"), text your ZIP code to 438829, or call 1-800-232-0233 to find locations in your area.__ - Studies show the vaccines are safe and effective. - Vaccines do not contain live virus - Gives you better protection than getting sick with COVID-19. - You can get COVID-19 again even if you’ve had it. - Vaccines will not change your DNA. - Side effects show that the vaccine is working to build your immunity to COVID-19. - Most people with medical conditions should get the vaccine. - You must keep taking steps to prevent COVID-19 after getting the vaccine.[^256] [Stay Up to Date with Your COVID-19 Vaccines](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html#vaccine-table "Stay Up to Date with Your COVID-19 Vaccines") ### Side Effects of Vaccine: Embedded content: https://youtu.be/rtSH6wXNnK0 - Pain and discomfort at the injection site - Swelling of the skin near injection site - Fever - Fatigue - Body chills - Headache [^257] ### Ways to Help Side Effects: - Put a clean, cold, & wet cloth over the injection site - Drink plenty of fluids - Dress lightly - Rest - Ask your doctor about these over-the-counter medications: - Acetaminophen - Ibuprofen - Aspirin - Antihistamines - Don’t take the medications above __before__ getting the vaccine. - Call your doctor if the side effects get worse after 24 to 48 hours. [^257] ### Common Questions and Answers: Embedded content: https://youtu.be/ZPENU08rZ-I #### Where can I get the vaccine? - __Use [Vaccines.gov](https://www.vaccines.gov/ "Vaccines.gov"), text your ZIP code to 438829, or call 1-800-232-0233 to find locations in your area.__ - Check your local retail pharmacy's website to find vaccination appointments. - Contact your [State Health Department](https://www.cdc.gov/publichealthgateway/healthdirectories/healthdepartments.html "State Health Department") to find vaccination locations.[^257] #### If I’m pregnant can I get the vaccine? - Yes, there is no evidence that fertility is affected by the COVID-19 vaccine. [^257] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/xcbnu5W9BBY [COVID-19 Vaccines for People Who Are Pregnant or Breastfeeding from the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/pregnancy.html "CDC Information About COVID-19 Vaccines for People Who Are Pregnant or Breastfeeding") #### Do I need to get the vaccine if I’ve had COVID-19? - Yes, because no one knows how long the protection from the COVID-19 infection will last. - You can get COVID-19 again even if you’ve had it. - If you were infected with COVID-19 and received the monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma, it is advised that you wait 90 days before receiving a COVID-19 vaccine. - Ask your doctor about any treatments you may have received when you had COVID-19 and if any of these may affect receiving a COVID-19 vaccine.[^257] #### After getting the vaccine, do I need to wear a mask, wash my hands, and social distance? - Wear a close-fitting mask over your nose and mouth indoors in public areas where the [COVID-19 Community Level](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/covid-by-county.html "COVID-19 Community Level") is __high__. - Avoid poorly ventilated indoor spaces if you are at a high risk of getting very sick from COVID-19.[^257] #### If I am sick with the COVID-19 infection, can I still receive a COVID-19 vaccination? - No. If you are sick with the COVID-19 infection, wait to receive a COVID-19 vaccine until you are fully recovered (this includes meeting the criteria for discontinuing self isolation).[^257] #### Can I still receive a COVID-19 vaccine with medical conditions? - Individuals with medical conditions are able to receive a COVID-19 vaccine, but they should not have had an immediate or severe allergic reaction to a COVID-19 vaccine or any ingredients in the vaccine. [^257] [Ingredient Information for Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/Pfizer-BioNTech.html) [Ingredient Information for Moderna COVID-19 vaccine](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/Moderna.html) Embedded content: https://youtu.be/Zhu2TyYkeNU #### What are the benefits of the vaccine? - COVID-19 vaccines produce protection from infection by allowing the body to develop an immune response to the virus that causes COVID-19. - By developing an immune protection to the SARS Cov2 virus, the chance of getting the COVID-19 infection or developing severe symptoms upon infection are much less. - This immunity will help to fight the infection. - Getting vaccinated can help you, your loved ones, and your community to stop the spread of COVID-19.[^257] #### How long will the COVID-19 vaccine protection last? - At this time the CDC is recommending a booster shot at least 5 months after the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccine series. - A booster shot is recommended at least 2 months after the J & J Janssen vaccine. [^257] [Frequently Asked Questions about COVID-19 Vaccination](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html "Frequently Asked Questions about COVID-19 Vaccinations.") ### Different Types of Vaccines: - mRNA by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna - DNA by Johnson & Johnson [^257] Embedded content: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mvA9gs5gxNY ### Coping with Stress: - Take breaks from the news and social media. - Eat well. - Care for yourself. - Walk, exercise, meditate, & listen to music. - Stay connected with others. - Get enough sleep. - Relax by doing activities you enjoy. - Avoid excessive alcohol, tobacco, & substance abuse. - Call your healthcare or mental health provider if you are struggling with stress.[^258] [Stress and Coping](https://www.cdc.gov/mentalhealth/stress-coping/index.html "Stress and Coping") ### Questions to Ask if Your Loved One is on a Ventilator: - When can they breathe on their own? - When can the sedation medication be reduced? - Does the patient have pressure sores on their back and/or buttocks? - Can the patient have a subglottic secretion drainage endotracheal tube if the ventilator will be in more than 72 hours? - Are the patient's teeth &/or dentures being cleaned twice a day? - Is the patient's mouth being rinsed with a non-alcohol based mouth rinse? - If the patient is at risk for aspiration will their teeth & mouth be cleaned 2-4 times a day with a suction toothbrush kit? - Is the patient being suctioned every 4 hours? - Is the patient’s head of the bed greater than 30 degrees? - Is everyone that sees the patient washing their hands? - Does the patient have a fever? - Is the patient feeling sick to their stomach? - Is the patient feeling sudden pain? - Does the patient have redness, swelling or tenderness at the airway insertion site? [^68] __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about your loved one.__ [The Hospital Plan of Care Form](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/POC-Blank-April-19.pdf "The Hospital Plan of Care form") [Guide to Medical Care at a Distance](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Guide-to-Medical-Care-at-a-Distance.pdf "Guide to Medical Care at a Distance") [^250]: Centers for Disease Control & Prevention.
